summary: Anal cancer is a type of cancer that forms in the tissues of the anus, the distal opening of the gastrointestinal tract. It is most commonly a squamous cell carcinoma and is strongly associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. Symptoms often include bleeding, lumps, pain, itching, discharge, and changes in bowel habits. Diagnosis typically involves physical exams, DRE, anoscopy, and biopsy, while treatment usually combines chemotherapy and radiation therapy, sometimes with surgery.
causes: Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection (especially high-risk types like HPV-16)
risk_factors: Weakened immune system (e.g., due to HIV/AIDS or organ transplant medicines)
symptoms: Bleeding from the anus or rectum
Pain in the area around the anus
Pressure in the area around the anus
Change in bowel habits (e.g., narrower stools, increased frequency, bowel incontinence)
diagnosis: Medical history (including symptoms and family health history)
Anal Pap smears (for screening high-risk individuals)
